description.narrative: Transparency International (TI) is a global anti-corruption movement. Tl's vision is a world in which government, business, civil society and the daily lives of people are free from corruption. TI is made up of more than 100 chapters worldwide, individual members, and an international Secretariat in Berlin. Since 1993, TI has campaigned for greater transparency and accountability in government and business. TI's mission is to stop corruption and promote transparency, accountability and integrity at all levels and across all sectors of society. The guiding document for the TI movement is the strategy 2020 "Together against corruption", which is implemented for the period 2016 to 2020. Sida’s support is to the TI Secretariat (TI-S) and for its lead in implementing the strategy 2020. Support to TI-S work is expected to contribute to the realization of the SDGS, especially goal 16 on good governance.

Transparency International is the world leading NGO in the field of anti-corruption. The Swedish contribution will support the implementation of TI-S Implementation Plan 2015, that contributes in achieveing the objectives in the TI Strategy 2015, support the development of a new strategy and the first year of implementation given that it is approved by Sida.

Transparency International är den världsledande NGOn inom korruptionsbekämpning. Den svenska insatsen kommer att stödja genomförandet av TI-S Implementation Plan 2015, som bidrar till att uppnå målen i TI rörelsens Strategi 2015, samt utvecklandet av en ny strategi och första årets implementering givet Sida godkännande.

description.narrative: Throughout the duration of the collaboration, TI played a key role in efforts to fight corruption around the world. As of August 2017, the TI movement was active in 112 countries. In its 2017 reporting to Sida, TI reported several key highlights, a few examples are included below: - The continuation of TI's relevance within global coalitions in implementing and monitoring the anti-corruption and governance targets of SDGs. For example, in 2017, TI developed alternative indicators for SDG 16. - During the reporting period TI also expanded its advocacy via the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC) and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). For example, TI played a significant role in putting the topic of Grand Corruption on the UNCAC Coalition agenda through namely discussions in the UNCAC Coalition Coordination Commission, and strategy development process. - Through TI's partnership with the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP), an in-depth investigation and publication of the ‘Azerbaijan Laundromat’ case exposed how corruption can affect human rights and democracy. - In 2017, TI published reports on Transparency in Corporate Reporting (TRAC) in the Ukraine, Vietnam, Lithuania, Russia, and Brazil and carried out Business Integrity Corporate Assessments (BICA) in Italy, Cambodia, Brazil and Mongolia. It is Sida's assessment that TI's results and achievements during 2017 (but also previously) are in line with the realization of the objectives. Looking forward, TI notes that in 2018, the organization will focus on 3 main areas: i) ending impunity for grand corruption; ii) public demand for ccountability; and, iii) promoting business integrity standards. For example, in 2018, TI will build on progress made in 2017 to end impunity for grand corruption and continue cooperation with investigative journalists who are working to reveal Grand Corruption cases. In addition, TI will increase its work with making governments and non-governmental institutions more open and accountable to citizens in order to reduce their opportunities for corruption. Upon Sida's request, TI submitted complementary reporting on challenges and lessons learnt for the reporting for the past two reporting periods. All the audits have been unqualified and have been in accordance with Sida's terms as stipulated in the agreement. During the past two years, no significant matters were identified in terms of internal control. In the management letter (at least for the past two years) several minor aspects were raised regarding improving more efficient internal processes. As the issues were minor, no formal management response from TI is required.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
